item.title: Corruption in Afghanistan All but Cripples Women’s Team Sports
item.media:description: Members of Afghanistan’s women’s national cycling team returning from training on the outskirts of Kabul in early April.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: With few exceptions, the programs are riddled with corruption and undermined by conservative Afghans who never liked the idea of young women on the field.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Abu Sayyaf Militants Thriving as Hostage-Takers in Philippines
item.media:description: A soldier in the southern town of Jolo in the Philippines on Tuesday. As soldiers continue to battle Abu Sayyaf, some analysts have begun to question whether the group can be defeated.
item.description: Crime, endemic corruption and poverty are fueling continued kidnappings by the Islamist fighters, despite government promises to wipe them out.
item.dc:creator: FLOYD WHALEY

item.title: Afghanistan’s Vice President Is Barred From Entering U.S.
item.media:description: Abdul Rashid Dostum, center, in rural Kunduz Province, outside the Afghan city of Kunduz, in 2014. The current Afghan president has called him a “known killer.”
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Officials denied a visa to Abdul Rashid Dostum, who is accused of war crimes but is also the No. 2 official in a government whose survival depends on American troops and money.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: In Effort to Defeat ISIS, U.S. and Iran Impede One Another
item.media:description: People fled their homes during fighting between Iraqi security forces and the Islamic State earlier this month in Anbar Province.
item.description: Civilians have been trapped in Falluja, where the Islamic State is under siege, and Shiite militias have stoked tensions elsewhere in Anbar Province.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Classified Pages From 9/11 Report Could Be Released by Summer
item.description: Amid speculation about a Saudi role in the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, several lawmakers have joined victims’ families in pushing for declassification.
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Egypt’s Security Agents Smother Streets of Cairo to Prevent Protests
item.media:description: Protesters in central Cairo on Monday. Demonstrations at several prearranged meeting spots never happened and impromptu rallies were quickly dispersed.
item.description: The intimidation effort seemed to work but also appeared to reveal anxiety by President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi over a growing chorus of critics.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: British Jury Faults Police Over 1989 Hillsborough Soccer Stadium Deaths
item.media:description: Relatives of Hillsborough victims in Warrington, England, on Tuesday after hearing the conclusions of the inquest into the 1989 disaster.
item.description: The 96 Liverpool fans who perished at a match in Sheffield, England, were the victims of police error or omission, the panel found.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Obama Outlines Goals Tempered by 8 Years of Foreign Policy Lessons
item.media:description: President Obama at a trade fair in Hanover, Germany, on Monday, the last day of his trip to Europe and the Middle East.
item.description: Mr. Obama, who as a candidate delivered a soaring speech in Berlin, gently urged allies on Monday to do more to defend themselves and solve their own problems.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: Trudeau Condemns Killing of Canadian Hostage in Philippines
item.description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada confirmed that the hostage, John Ridsdel, was killed by Abu Sayyaf militants after a ransom deadline expired.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Few Expect Mexico’s Government to Suffer at Polls, Despite Outrage Over Abductions
item.media:description: Felipe de la Cruz, the father of a missing student, in Mexico City on Monday. An investigative panel has accused the government of stonewalling.
item.description: As protests have dwindled over the official investigation into the disappearance of 43 students, many fear the ruling party will face few political consequences.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Escuela Normal Rural Raul Isidro Burgos (Guerrero, Mexico)

item.title: Deadly Ethnic Strife Convulses Ethiopia-South Sudan Border
item.description: Ethiopians who belong to the Nuer ethnic group say they no longer feel safe, after being targeted by compatriots known as highlanders.
item.dc:creator: JACEY FORTIN

item.title: Papua New Guinea Finds Australian Offshore Detention Center Illegal
item.media:description: A detention center financed by Australia on Manus Island in northern Papua New Guinea in 2012. More than 800 men who tried to reach Australia by boat in recent years are being held here.
item.media:credit: Australian Department of Immigration and Citizenship, via Getty Images
item.description: An Australian official said the ruling would not mean that the asylum seekers being held at the island center would be admitted to the country.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Taiwan Party Organizer Sentenced to Nearly 5 Years in Water Park Fire
item.media:description: Relatives of victims of an explosion at a water park last year displaying placards calling for justice.
item.description: Fifteen people were killed and hundreds badly injured in June after flammable color powder ignited at the party, causing an explosion.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Yemen Retakes Oil Export Terminal From Al Qaeda
item.description: Yemeni forces and allies from the United Arab Emirates regained control of the Ash Shihr terminal on Monday from Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula

item.title: Pro-European Union Party in Serbia Wins Election in Landslide
item.description: The results of Sunday’s vote, presented by the state electoral commission on Monday, also showed that pro-Russian nationalists would return to Parliament.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: ISIS Spreading in Europe, U.S. Intelligence Chief Warns
item.media:description: James R. Clapper Jr., the director of national intelligence, in February in Washington. When asked on Monday if the Islamic State was engaging in secret activities in in Britain, Germany and Italy, he said, “Yes, they do. That is a concern, obviously, of ours and our European allies.”
item.media:credit: Drew Angerer for The New York Times
item.description: James R. Clapper Jr. warned of clandestine cells in Britain, Germany and Italy resembling the groups that carried out the Paris and Brussels terrorist attacks.
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT and ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Iran Threatens Lawsuit in Hague Court Over U.S. Ruling on $2 Billion
item.description: It is unclear, however, whether the International Court of Justice will have jurisdiction in Iran’s complaint.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Qi Benyu, Mao Aide With No Remorse After China’s Cultural Revolution, Dies at 84
item.media:description: Qi Benyu, in an undated photograph, lauded Mao Zedong.
item.description: Mr. Qi, a propagandist in the Chinese Communist Party, remained unrepentant over the revolution and steadfast in his admiration of Mao Zedong.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: China Curbs Plans for More Coal-Fired Power Plants
item.media:description: Residents living near a coal-fired power plant in Shanxi, China, wear masks for protection from air pollution.
item.description: The country, the world’s biggest emitter of greenhouse gases, halted plans for new coal-fired plants and postponed building of some already approved.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Bangladesh Gay Rights Activist Is Hacked to Death
item.media:description: The bodies of a gay rights activist and his friend, both hacked to death with machetes, were brought down on Monday from an apartment in Dhaka, Bangladesh.
item.description: Julhas Mannan, who had helped organize a march for gay and transgender youths, was the victim of what the police believe to be the latest in a wave of targeted killings.
item.dc:creator: JULFIKAR ALI MANIK and ELLEN BARRY
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Agency for International Development

item.title: Global Health: Tanzanian Women Face High Rates of Abortion-Related Deaths
item.media:description: A woman was hospitalized in Berega, Tanzania, after what may have been a botched abortion.
item.media:credit: Béatrice de Géa for The New York Times
item.description: According to a recent study, deaths result from several factors and women in some regions die much more often than others.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: Ex-Presidents of Poland Issue a Rebuke to the Governing Party
item.description: An open letter from three former presidents, including Lech Walesa, and seven other politicians said the new right-wing government was a threat to democracy.
item.dc:creator: DARA BRAMSON

item.title: Saudi Prince Shares Plan to Cut Oil Dependency and Energize the Economy
item.media:description: Saudis at the Amex Luxury Expo in Riyadh this month. Taxes on luxury items are being introduced to make up for lost oil revenue.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: The plan aims to steer Saudi Arabia through a drop in oil prices and a demographic shift to a significantly youthful population.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Uighur Activist in Germany Sees China’s Hand in Revocation of Indian Visa
item.media:description: Dolkun Isa is a leader of the World Uyghur Congress.
item.description: Dolkun Isa, who fled China in 1994 and was labeled a terrorist, had been scheduled to meet the Dalai Lama.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: China Close to Passing Strict Law on Foreign Groups
item.media:description: A slogan being projected by Greenpeace China onto the Yongdingmen Gate in Beijing in 2009. A proposed law would subject foreign groups to oversight by the police.
item.description: Critics say the proposed bill would curtail important work by nongovernmental organizations in the country, like legal assistance and programs promoting the rule of law.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China

item.title: Memo From Spain: Discord Pushes Spain Into Fifth Month With No Government
item.media:description: Mariano Rajoy, the acting prime minister of Spain, during a debate in Parliament this month.
item.description: Spain is giving Belgium a run for its money in the political discord category. Some are comparing the atmosphere in the country to a circus.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: 1916 Easter Rising in Ireland, a Milestone of Foreign Reporting
item.media:description: Destruction in Dublin in May 1916, after the Easter Rising.
item.media:credit: Topical Press Agency, via Getty Images
item.description: Intense coverage of the five-day rebellion, whose centennial is this week, reflected in part the growing clout of Irish America, historians say.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK

item.title: U.S. to Increase Military Presence in Syria, Obama Says
item.description: President Obama, whose comments came in a speech in which he pressed for European unity, said he would add 250 military personnel to the 50 already on the ground.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: Afghan President Demands Pakistan Take Military Action Against Taliban
item.description: President Ashraf Ghani dropped his conciliatory approach and threatened to go to the United Nations if Pakistan failed to strike the Taliban on its soil.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Australia Charges Teenager With Plotting Anzac Day Terror Attack
item.description: The boy, 16, was arrested the day before the veterans’ commemorations, after he was said to have tried to obtain a firearm, according to news reports.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Britain Grapples With Enduring Questions of Religion and Race
item.media:description: Sadiq Khan, 45, is the Labour Party candidate for mayor of London. If Mr. Khan wins the May 5 election, he would be the first Muslim to lead the city that dominates Britain’s economic, cultural and political life, and where nearly one in eight residents is Muslim.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: As the country engages in fierce debates centered on national identity, it is also confronting challenges to traditional norms of political discourse.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER and STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Grauer’s Gorillas May Soon Be Extinct, Conservationists Say
item.media:description: Gorillas in the Democratic Republic of Congo.
item.description: Over the last two decades, the population of the world’s largest primate has fallen 77 percent, a decline hidden by conflict in the region.
item.dc:creator: RACHEL NUWER

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Mexico’s Self-Image Problem
item.description: Investigators say Mexico stonewalled their inquiry into the deaths of 43 college students. But officials seem more concerned about Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: GINGER THOMPSON

item.title: Editorial: A Risky American Expansion in Syria
item.media:description: President Obama in Germany on Monday.
item.description: What does adding more troops mean for the United States’ future involvement in that war?
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: A Greek View of Brexit
item.description: For two centuries, Greece and Britain have been tied together. Now both nations, from very different positions, pose a serious threat to the E.U.
item.dc:creator: NIKOS KONSTANDARAS

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN

item.title: Dispatch from Dakar: ‘Where Is This Flight Going?’ and Other Basic Questions About African Travel
item.media:description: A moldy airplane on the runway in Cameroon.
item.description: In West Africa, getting there is way more than half the battle.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: How ISIS Built the Machinery of Terror Under Europe’s Gaze
item.media:description: The Paris attacks left 130 dead in November, but a branch within the Islamic State was obsessed with striking Europe at least two years before then.
item.description: Two years before the Paris and Brussels assaults, a special branch of the group was churning out smaller attacks that the authorities repeatedly discounted as isolated or random acts.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
